author: By Katrina Miller
title: Don’t Miss Comet Nishimura This Weekend, a Once-in-a-Lifetime View
description: For the next few mornings, just before sunrise, the cosmic snowball will glow green low on the horizon.
content: Astronomy aficionados are buzzing about a bright new comet. The ball of dust and ice is formally named C/2023 P1, but is also called Comet Nishimura, for Hideo Nishimura, the Japanese photographer who first spotted it. And you may have an opportunity to see it as well during the next few nights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Newsom to Democrats: ‘Buck Up’ and Back Biden
description: The California governor has become the most visible Democrat-in-waiting. His support of the president is a key part of his effort to put himself forward for the next campaign.
content: Over the past four months, Gavin Newsom, the Democratic governor of California, has traveled to six Republican-led states. He has goaded Gov. Ron DeSantis, the Republican presidential candidate from Florida, to debate on Fox News. He has assembled a small staff of political advisers and created a political action committee to distribute $10 million to Democratic causes and candidates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Living and Dying in ¾ Time
description: As Jimmy Buffett sang, ‘The sunrise’ll bring on the sleep that escaped us.’
content: WASHINGTON — Whenever I take my young researchers on celebrity interviews, I give them the Warning: No matter how well you hit it off, don’t feel bad if you ever run into the stars again and they act as though they don’t know you. That’s usually how it goes. Think of them as elusive, shimmering creatures from another planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch, Michael J. de la Merced and Ravi Mattu
title: Saudi Arabia Is Pouring Money in Sports. Is Tennis Next?
description: Despite the popularity of tennis, its business has struggled.
content: The U.S. Open has been as gripping as ever this year, with  the 19-year-old breakout star Coco Gauff set to face off against Aryna Sabalenka in today’s singles final and Novak Djokovic seeking a 24th Grand Slam win tomorrow. But as a business, tennis has been struggling for years — and faces new pressure to find a sustainable model as Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund, known as P.I.F., has made major investments in sports, sloshing money around in golf, soccer and mixed martial arts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Adam Goldman, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: He Was Just the I.T. Guy. Then He Got Caught in the Trump Documents Case.
description: Yuscil Taveras is among the little-known people with links to Donald Trump to have come under scrutiny. So far, he’s the only Trump employee known to have agreed to cooperate with prosecutors after facing charges.
content: One day in June of last year, at a time when federal investigators were demanding security footage from former President Donald J. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate, Yuscil Taveras shared an explosive secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Physical and Spiritual Awakening (but No Steady Paycheck)
description: To make a company, George Balanchine first needed to make dancers. At 75, New York City Ballet pays tribute to its dancers, including three who were there at the start.
content: There were moments of total exhaustion. A young dancer, having performed a difficult matinee and faced with an evening show, slipped into her dressing room. She placed something soft on the ground to cushion her body from the cement floor. She lay down. She listened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Elon Musk Wants to Save Humanity. The Only Problem: People.
description: Walter Isaacson’s biography of the billionaire entrepreneur depicts a mercurial “man-child” with grandiose ambitions and an ego to match.
content: At various moments in “Elon Musk,” Walter Isaacson’s new biography of the world’s richest person, the author tries to make sense of the billionaire entrepreneur he has shadowed for two years — sitting in on meetings, getting a peek at emails and texts, engaging in “scores of interviews and late-night conversations.” Musk is a mercurial “man-child,” Isaacson writes, who was bullied relentlessly as a kid in South Africa until he grew big enough to beat up his bullies. Musk talks about having Asperger’s, which makes him “bad at picking up social cues.” As the people closest to him will attest, he lacks empathy — something that Isaacson describes as a “gene” that’s “hard-wired.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Why Is Joe Biden So Unpopular?
description: Four possible explanations, no definite solutions.
content: Joe Biden is an unpopular president, and without some recovery, he could easily lose to Donald Trump in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Whim-Whams
description: Robert S. Gard makes a soaring debut.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid is the New York Times debut for Robert S. Gard, whose byline was featured on a couple of themed Wall Street Journal crosswords this summer. The puzzle feels sophisticated for someone’s first crack at a themeless; in particular, there are many nice teases in the cluing that exhibit a roguish sense of humor. There’s enough here to make this a true Saturday — misdirects, but also a generous amount of obscurity that I had to uncover letter by letter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: The Pennsylvania Fugitive: Why Wasn’t He Deported?
description: Undocumented immigrants accused of minor crimes are often sent back to their homelands. Danelo Cavalcante, who escaped from a U.S. prison, had been facing a murder charge in Brazil.
content: At an unknown time and at an unknown location, Danelo Souza Cavalcante, a 34-year-old citizen of Brazil, entered the United States unlawfully — without being inspected or admitted by a U.S. immigration official, according to the Department of Homeland Security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: ‘I’m Being Indicted for You,’ Trump Tells South Dakota Rally
description: In his first rally since his fourth indictment, the former president focused on his Republican rivals and President Biden, as some in the crowd wore Mr. Trump’s mug shot on their T-shirts.
content: When Donald J. Trump came to South Dakota in July 2020, then a president in the middle of his re-election campaign, he stood in front of Mount Rushmore and outlined a dark vision of what he claimed his opponents on the left would do to the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constance Sommer
title: The High-Wire Act of Caregiving and Saving for Retirement
description: More states are establishing paid leave programs that could help caregivers protect their nest eggs.
content: Tara Driver would love to retire before age 70. But it’s not going to be easy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Ex-Soldier Who Escaped From U.K. Prison Is Recaptured in London
description: The fugitive broke out by strapping himself under a food delivery van. He was arrested three days later just miles away.
content: Three days after a former British soldier facing terrorism charges engineered an audacious escape from a London prison, setting off an intense nationwide manhunt, he was captured by the police on Saturday morning, only a dozen miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Vietnam Chases Secret Russian Arms Deal, Even as It Deepens U.S. Ties
description: Defying U.S. sanctions, a Vietnamese government document lays out a plan to buy Russian weapons, which officials see as a way to upgrade its military as a hedge against China.
content: When President Biden is greeted by Vietnamese officials in Hanoi on Sunday, he will be celebrating the prospect of adding another friend in Asia to a coalition that his administration hopes will side with American interests rather than China’s and Russia’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Why Some Ex-Workers at Bed Bath & Beyond Face 401(k) Losses
description: Federal law generally protects retirement savings when a company files for bankruptcy. But that’s not always the case.
content: Federal law generally protects savings in workers’ retirement plans when a company files for bankruptcy protection or goes out of business. Yet there may still be situations when employees lose money, as some former workers at Bed Bath & Beyond have discovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Mangosuthu Buthelezi, Zulu Nationalist and a Mandela Rival, Dies at 95
description: He was a powerful force as apartheid ended and bargaining over South Africa’s future began, emerging as a voice for tribal and ethnic rights, and powers for regional governments.
content: Mangosuthu Buthelezi, the Zulu nationalist who positioned himself as Nelson Mandela’s most powerful Black rival in South Africa’s tortuous transformation from a white segregationist society to a multiracial democracy in the 1990s, died on Saturday. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: What Is the G20 and What Does It Do?
description: The Group of 20 nations aims to unite world leaders around shared challenges. Here is what to know as this year’s summit meeting kicks off in India.
content: Established in 1999 after a series of major international debt crises, the Group of 20 aims to unite world leaders around shared economic, political and health challenges. Here is a look at what the group is and does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: The Long Life and Long Reach of George Balanchine’s Butterflies
description: Balanchine didn’t think his ballets would last. But many have become classics, the cornerstone of repertory not just at City Ballet but around the world.
content: While celebrating its 75th anniversary this fall, New York City Ballet is performing 18 ballets by its founding choreographer, George Balanchine. But to get a sense of the global standing of Balanchine, 40 years after his death, other numbers might be more telling. Last year, for instance, around 50 other ballet companies across the world performed his works, about 75 dances in total.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers
title: Appeals Court Rules White House Overstepped 1st Amendment on Social Media
description: A Fifth Circuit panel partly upheld restrictions on the Biden administration’s communications with online platforms about their content.
content: A federal appeals court ruled on Friday that the Biden administration most likely overstepped the First Amendment by urging the major social media platforms to remove misleading or false content about the Covid-19 pandemic, partly upholding a lower court’s preliminary injunction in a victory for conservatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Citing Costs of Migrant Care, Adams Calls for More Budget Cuts
description: The mayor ordered New York City agencies to reduce spending by 15 percent in the coming months, but said that federal and state aid could prevent the need for cuts.
content: Days after saying that an influx of over 110,000 asylum seekers was destroying New York City, Mayor Eric Adams on Saturday directed every city agency to submit plans to reduce spending by up to 15 percent, while renewing his calls for state and federal help to manage the migrant crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Sept. 2-8
description: The cream rose in finding this week’s most challenging word.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Your Fall Movie Preview
description: Let’s take a look at some of the most exciting films coming soon.
content: Searching for something to look forward to in the last light of summer, the fall movie schedule beckons. When the sun sets too early, what better refuge than the movies, where Annette Bening is playing Diana Nyad (October), Colman Domingo plays Bayard Rustin (November) and Timothée Chalamet is Willy Wonka (December)? Transformations! Oh, to enter a theater, see something spectacular and emerge a little transformed, too!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: I’m Not a Joiner. Was I Born That Way?
description: Is it personality, nurture, life stage or even genes that make one long to be part of groups?
content: When I was writing my series on Americans’ declining interest in organized religion, I laid my cards on the table: I will always define myself as Jewish, but I have little desire to go to temple. When I started my reporting, I was somewhat ambivalent about my lack of traditional observance as an adult. I went to temple growing up and I’m proud of my heritage and the values I consider to be Jewish. I believe it’s important to pass those values along to my children, but I was concerned that without the structure of regular in-person worship, intergenerational transmission would be more difficult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Spider-Man 2’s New York Is a Web of Skyscrapers and Brownstones
description: The sequel to the 2018 video game will let players scour three boroughs in a love letter to the city and its Spidey savior.
content: Reality and fantasy were deeply intertwined in Marvel’s Spider-Man, where gamers swung from webs above Lincoln Center and leaped from the Empire State Building’s spire into the crowds leaving the subway station at Herald Square. The comic book icon also brought his own landmarks to that version of New York City, which hosted the Avengers headquarters a few blocks north of the United Nations and a supervillain prison in the East River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron E. Carroll
title: What Obesity Drugs and Antidepressants Have in Common
description: The more misunderstood the health condition, the more we moralize its treatment.
content: We like to think we understand the drugs we take, especially after rigorous trials have proved their efficacy and safety. But sometimes, we know only that medications work; we just don’t know why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Verdict on the New Helmut Lang
description: Can Peter Do reinvent the brand that once defined haute cool?
content: Once, back in the early 2000s, I owned a black Helmut Lang pantsuit. That was a time when even the word “pantsuit” kind of made me cringe, but there was something about how this one was cut — three-button, single-breasted jacket and flat-front (but louche) pants — that skewed all its establishment implications. It made me feel like both the coolest and the most grown-up versions of myself, as if I were a person who could talk to anyone, could go into any room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Max Gomez, Longtime TV Medical Reporter, Dies at 72
description: Known as Dr. Max (he was not a medical doctor. but had a Ph.D. in neuroscience), he reported on health and science with an easygoing gravitas.
content: Max Gomez, an award-winning medical and science journalist who delivered informed reports for more than 40 years on TV stations in New York and Philadelphia, most recently during the Covid-19 pandemic, died on Sept. 2 at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Rat-Infested, Will Canada’s Most Famous Fixer-Upper Be Replaced?
description: Leaked information suggests that security concerns may force officials to build a new house to replace 24 Sussex Drive, the derelict and abandoned official residence of Canada’s prime ministers.
content: The saga of 24 Sussex Drive, the derelict onetime official residence of Canada’s prime ministers, took a new turn last week after a news leak signaled that the fate of the home — Canada’s most famous fixer-upper — could soon be decided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Keppler
title: I Stopped Paying My Private Student Loans, and Somehow Got Lucky
description: One borrower’s story about falling behind on payments, defaulting on his private student loans and waiting out the statute of limitations on debt collection.
content: When the Supreme Court struck down President Biden’s plan to cancel up to $20,000 in federal student loan debt in June, I was one of 43 million people whose financial future took a hit. I had $10,459 in federal loans at stake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: ‘Zip Tie Guy’ and His Mother Get Prison Terms in Jan. 6 Riot
description: Eric Munchel, 32, of Tennessee, was sentenced to nearly five years in prison in connection with the attack on the U.S. Capitol in 2021, while his mother, Lisa Eisenhart, 59, received a two-and-a-half-year term.
content: A Tennessee man and his mother were sentenced to prison on Friday for seeking to intimidate lawmakers by marching with matching tactical vests and carrying zip tie-style handcuffs during the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, federal prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: The Technology Facebook and Google Didn’t Dare Release
description: Engineers at the tech giants built tools years ago that could put a name to any face but, for once, Silicon Valley did not want to move fast and break things.
content: One afternoon in early 2017, at Facebook’s headquarters in Menlo Park, Calif., an engineer named Tommer Leyvand sat in a conference room with a smartphone standing on the brim of his baseball cap. Rubber bands helped anchor it in place with the camera facing out. The absurd hat-phone, a particularly uncool version of the future, contained a secret tool known only to a small group of employees. What it could do was remarkable.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 9, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 9, 2023.
content: An article on Monday about torrential rains that left thousands stranded at Burning Man festival misstated the name of the piano bar where the musician known as ELEW performed. It is called the Black Rock Piano Lounge, not Playa Piano Bar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: ‘Stop Making Sense’ Is Back, and Talking Heads Have More to Say
description: The 40th-anniversary restoration of a great concert film is a funk spectacle. It has also united the band, which split in 1991, to discuss a landmark achievement.
content: Four decades after it was filmed, “Stop Making Sense,” the Talking Heads concert documentary, is still ecstatic and strange. “It stays kind of relevant, even though it doesn’t make literal sense,” David Byrne, the band’s leader and singer, said in a recent interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Maria Cramer
title: New Deal Will Test Whether N.Y.P.D. Can Alter Its Response to Protests
description: Protests in New York City have long helped shape social change in the United States, sometimes at a cost. A court settlement may change the dynamics of such events.
content: Protesters were thousands-thick in Tompkins Square Park in Manhattan’s East Village when the police moved in with horses and nightsticks. The tactics were described by a labor leader as “an orgy of brutality” and brought a public outcry demanding that police officials be fired.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tumultuous Family Stories, Two Ways
description: Dissolving a marriage; raising a granddaughter.
content: Dear readers,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: The U.S. Open Men’s Singles Final We Only Half Expected: Djokovic vs. Medvedev
description: Novak Djokovic will be playing for his 24th Grand Slam title. Daniil Medvedev will be conjuring his 2021 Open outcome.
content: From the day the men’s singles draw came out, the path for Novak Djokovic to reach yet another U.S. Open final seemed clear, and seemed to set up for a showdown with Carlos Alcaraz, which would have been a rematch of this year’s Wimbledon final.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Here’s how to help victims of the earthquake.
description: Here’s how to contribute to organizations that are aiding the rescue and recovery efforts in Morocco.
content: The powerful earthquake that struck Morocco late Friday night killed at least 1,000 people, with at least several hundred more injured. It was the strongest to hit the area in more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Marc Bohan, Head Designer for Dior for Three Decades, Dies at 97
description: As the creative force for Christian Dior longer than its founder, he maintained a reputation for playful elegance throughout fashion’s endless cycles.
content: Marc Bohan, the longest-serving creative director at Christian Dior, who spent nearly 30 years spinning out classically attuned looks with a touch of whimsy that, however resplendent, were meant to be worn, not gazed at on mannequins or in fashion magazines, died on Wednesday in Châtillon-sur-Seine, France. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: New York Employers Are Eager to Hire Migrants. They Can’t.
description: Many Democrats and business leaders favor giving migrants work permits, but pockets of tension and reluctance have created a complex political calculus.
content: Outside Albany, N.Y., where hundreds of recent migrants have been bused upstate from New York City, David Buicko sees an obvious solution to the labor shortage he and other employers are experiencing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yael Goldstein-Love
title: Get the Baby to the Doctor
description: In a strange city, a new mother’s routine errand becomes absolutely everything.
content: I had a baby, a crumbling relationship and not one friend in the city we had moved to three weeks earlier, other than the partner I was losing. So naturally I fixated on an errand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Detours Ahead
description: Adam Wagner’s puzzle gets us moving.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: How Lauren Groff, One of ‘Our Finest Living Writers,’ Does Her Work
description: Groff works on several novels at once, composes in longhand, and wrote a draft of her new book, “The Vaster Wilds,” in iambic pentameter “just for fun.”
content: Lauren Groff, the three-time National Book Award finalist, was marching through the woods of New Hampshire, her pants stuffed into her socks to keep out the ticks. Two muddy dogs jogged ahead of her and a reporter trotted along behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Trump’s Resilience Leaves Anxious G.O.P. Donors in Despair and Denial
description: The party’s big donors have made clear their distaste for the former president. Now, as he barrels toward the nomination, they are reacting with a mix of hand-wringing, calls to arms and fatalism.
content: On Labor Day, Eric Levine, a New York lawyer and Republican fund-raiser, sent an email to roughly 1,500 donors, politicians and friends.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Keeping Monkeys at Bay Part of G20 Preparations
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, September 9, 2023.
content: “The monkeys are naughty and they can arrive at your dinner table, in any house in Delhi.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Weike Wang
title: An Electric Novel About Space, a Poignant Story About Loss
description: In her new novel, “Digging Stars,” Novuyo Rosa Tshuma explores science, identity and grief through a young astronomer who immigrates to America after her father dies mysteriously.
content: The Digging Stars is a star cluster known by many names. It is most commonly called the Pleiades. Depending on who and where you are, it’s also referred to as the Seven Sisters or isiLimela, among other things. But no matter its name, in Novuyo Rosa Tshuma’s excellent debut novel, “Digging Stars,” the cluster is a force, a symbol, a family heirloom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Coco Gauff and Aryna Sabalenka Will Play for the U.S. Open Championship
description: Gauff, 19, is the first American teenager to reach the singles final in New York since Serena Williams in 2001.
content: Follow live updates on the U.S. Open women’s final between Coco Gauff and Aryna Sabalenka.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Graham and Katie Currid
title: A Miracle in Missouri? The Nun Who Put Her Abbey on the Map.
description: Four years after her death, the body of Sister Wilhelmina Lancaster has not decomposed, her fellow nuns said. Believers come from all over to see for themselves.
content: In life, Sister Wilhelmina Lancaster was known to her fellow nuns for her devotional poetry, her sense of humor and her fierce piety. “I’m Sister Wil-hel-mina,” she was known to say. “I’ve a hell of a will and I mean it!” A biography published by her order after her death at age 95 in 2019 described her as the little nun “who persevered in faith.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: The Call
description: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Scheck and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: In Ukraine, a U.S. Arms Dealer Is Making a Fortune and Testing Limits
description: Billions are pouring into a clubby, secretive arms market. With Pentagon cash and unusually close Ukrainian military ties, Marc Morales has few peers.
content: A half-dozen or so men gathered last month for afternoon drinks at the penthouse bar of one of Kyiv’s swankiest hotels to discuss the lucrative business of arming Ukrainian troops.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Path to Happiness: Career or Marriage?
description: Readers debate David Brooks’s advice to young people to prioritize marriage.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters, Niraj Chokshi and Benjamin Mullin
title: ‘I’m Not Trump’s Fan’ and Other Takeaways From a New Book on Elon Musk
description: The biography, by Walter Isaacson, portrays Mr. Musk as a complex, tortured figure.
content: A new biography of Elon Musk portrays the billionaire entrepreneur as a complex, tortured figure whose brilliance is often overshadowed by his inability to relate on a human level to the people around him — his wives, his children and those on whom he relied to help develop the space exploration and electric car businesses that made him the wealthiest man on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pierre-Antoine Louis
title: How These Artists Learn From Each Other
description: Nari Ward and Cosmo Whyte are from different generations, but their approaches are similar.
content: This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: G20 Declaration Omits Criticism of Russia, Notes Ukrainians’ ‘Suffering’
description: American officials defended the agreement, saying it built on the statement released last year and that the United States was still pressing for peace in Ukraine.
content: A painstakingly negotiated declaration Saturday evening at the Group of 20 summit in New Delhi omitted any condemnation of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine or its brutal conduct of the war, instead lamenting the “suffering” of the Ukrainian people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan O'Grady
title: In This Dark Fairy Tale, the Beauty Industry Is the Villain
description: Mona Awad’s new novel, “Rouge,” indicts the quest to be fairest of them all.
content: At what point, a woman approaching a landmark birthday might wonder, has one fully surrendered to the beauty industry? Is it when the products in our morning routine exceed available shelf space, or the day we find ourselves electrocuting our faces in pursuit of “lift”? Do we measure vanity in the number of hair, skin and nail appointments on our calendars, or in the frequency of ads for collagen gummies cranked out by our social media algorithms?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Louisville to Pay $20 Million to Two Wrongly Convicted Men
description: Garr Keith Hardin and Jeffrey Clark spent decades of a life sentence in jail for a murder conviction. They were exonerated in 2018.
content: Two Kentucky men who spent 22 years in jail for an unsolved 1992 murder they did not commit agreed this week to settle a civil rights case against Louisville for $20.5 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alicia Parlapiano and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Does Obamacare Explain Medicare’s Spending Slowdown?
description: Readers offered theories of their own on a big budget mystery.
content: Medicare may just be the budget buster that wasn’t. Somehow, after decades of nonstop growth, its spending per person has flattened over the past dozen years, saving taxpayers roughly $3.9 trillion since 2011, according to an Upshot analysis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: J.F.K. Assassination Witness Breaks His Silence and Raises New Questions
description: The account of Paul Landis, one of the Secret Service agents just feet away from John F. Kennedy when he was struck down, could change the understanding of what happened in Dallas in 1963.
content: He still remembers the first gunshot. For an instant, standing on the running board of the motorcade car, he entertained the vain hope that maybe it was just a firecracker or a blown tire. But he knew guns and he knew better. Then came another shot. And another. And the president slumped down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Serious Earthquakes Have Hit Morocco Before
description: The deadliest quake in Morocco’s recent history was a 5.8-magnitude temblor that killed about 12,000 people in 1960.
content: Serious earthquakes in Morocco, which the U.S. Geological Survey calls “uncommon but not unexpected,” have inflicted deaths and significant economic damage before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: The Threads of Identity in a Palestinian Craft
description: Traditional Palestinian embroidery is on UNESCO’s list of cultural heritage. Now there is a push to revive interest in the craft among younger generations.
content: In every stitch, there is a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Poor Things’ Takes Top Prize at Venice Film Festival
description: The film, directed by Yorgos Lanthimos, stars Emma Stone as a woman who goes on a sexual and philosophical journey. The announcement of its win was met with a roar of applause.
content: “Poor Things,” directed by Yorgos Lanthimos, was awarded the Golden Lion for best film at the 80th Venice International Film Festival on Saturday by a competition jury led by Damien Chazelle. The film stars Emma Stone in a virtuoso performance as a woman  with an initially childlike understanding of the world who comes into her own through a sexual and philosophical journey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson, Aida Alami, Aurelien Breeden and Constant Méheut
title: Powerful Earthquake Shakes Morocco, Killing More Than 2,000
description: The quake, centered in the mountains just outside of Marrakesh, was the strongest to hit that area in a century. “It didn’t last long, but felt like years,” said one woman who lives near the epicenter.
content: A powerful earthquake struck Morocco on Friday night, killing more than 2,000 people and setting off frantic rescue efforts through rubble-strewn city streets and remote rural areas as some residents sifted through mountains of debris with their bare hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: New York City Ballet Was in Peril. Then Came a Revival.
description: The company has rebounded after the pandemic and a series of scandals, stabilizing its finances, revamping its culture and attracting younger audiences.
content: The leaders of New York City Ballet filed into a banquet hall at Lincoln Center one day in the spring of 2022 for an urgent meeting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: In Post-Roe America, Nikki Haley Seeks a New Path on Abortion for G.O.P.
description: In crafting an anti-abortion message that doesn’t alienate moderate Republicans and swing voters, her approach has won both supporters and detractors.
content: In May 2016, Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina walked down the aisle of the statehouse, beaming and shaking hands, after signing legislation that would largely outlaw abortion in the state after 20 weeks of pregnancy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: Beware the Men Who Double Down
description: People like Luis Rubiales and Donald Trump cannot be shamed for their behavior because they fundamentally believe it is acceptable.
content: When Luis Rubiales, the president of Spain’s soccer federation, faced global backlash for kissing Jenni Hermoso, a member of the Spanish team that won the Women’s World Cup, he did not exhibit remorse or embarrassment. Nor did he when Ms. Hermoso and her teammates announced they would never work with him again. Nor when FIFA, the world soccer authority, suspended him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrey Henkin
title: Richard Davis, Gifted Bassist Who Crossed Genres, Dies at 93
description: He was best known for his jazz work. But he was also heard on Van Morrison’s “Astral Weeks” and with orchestras conducted by Igor Stravinsky and Leonard Bernstein.
content: Richard Davis, an esteemed bassist who played not just with some of the biggest names in jazz but also with major figures in the classical, pop and rock worlds, died on Wednesday. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Scenes From Morocco: A Deadly Earthquake Strikes
description: The quake about 50 miles from Marrakesh turned residences into rubble and left the survivors terrified.
content: A magnitude-6.8 earthquake struck about 50 miles from the city of Marrakesh in the High Atlas Mountains of Morocco, killing more than 2,000 people, turning houses and buildings into rubble and terrifying residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: My Windows Are Filthy and the Landlord Won’t Clean Them
description: It’s not just dirt that dims city views. Windows are often caked in air pollutants that pose a health hazard.
content: Q: I’ve lived in a rent-stabilized apartment in Hudson Heights for almost seven years and have no real complaints except for one thing: The windows are absolutely filthy! I called the management company to see if it has a preferred window-cleaning service, to no avail. When I asked if I could hire my own cleaner, management said no. I am on the third floor and cannot clean the windows, because they are old and do not open into the apartment. I have called 311, and they were very good about window guards and the like, but there don’t seem to be any rules about upkeep and cleaning. Can you help?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: The 19th Century’s Most Scandalous Painting Comes to New York
description: “Olympia,” the brothel scene that birthed modern art, crosses the Atlantic for the first time in the Met exhibition “Manet/Degas.”
content: “A colossal ineptitude,” one enraged critic called it. “Her face is stupid,” another wrote. The papers declared it “shapeless,” “putrefied,” “incomprehensible.” They said it “recalls the horror of the morgue.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: How a Chef and Bronx Evangelist Spends His Sundays
description: Pierre Serrao, co-founder of the Bronx culinary collective Ghetto Gastro, catches up with friends over a homemade feast.
content: As one-third of the Bronx culinary collective Ghetto Gastro, Pierre Serrao naturally spends his Sundays in the kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliette Guéron-Gabrielle
title: In Search of Cool Green Spaces, Paris Turns to an Old Rail Line
description: The French capital is converting the tracks into semi-wild oases to provide relief as climate change brings hotter days, although the nature that has flourished there may pay a price.
content: Across the street from a block of dense office buildings in western Paris, Bernard Sokler was surrounded by trees, weeds and crickets, as he tended to a bush of purple wildflowers in a largely forgotten strip of land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Leatherby, Marco Hernandez, Elena Shao and Karen Yourish
title: Maps: Where the Earthquake Struck Morocco
description: See where the earthquake caused major damage in cities and towns in southern Morocco.
content: See where the earthquake caused major damage in cities and towns in southern Morocco.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Devastating Earthquake in Morocco Kills More Than 2,000 People
description: An earthquake with a magnitude of at least 6.8 shook much of Morocco, the strongest to hit the area in more than a century.
content: An earthquake with a magnitude of at least 6.8 shook much of Morocco, the strongest to hit the area in more than a century.
source.name: The New York Times
